Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Predicting and Preventing Mold Growth and Unforeseen HVAC Equipment Failures with an Intelligent Monitoring and Alerting System
Award.AbstractNarration:
This I-Corps project will increase a customerâ€™s ability to identify and mitigate mold and HVAC issues before they happen, allowing them to better allocate their resources and ultimately save money and maintain a healthy atmosphere and reduce waste. The core technology is centered around a holistic approach to indoor air quality (IAQ) and HVAC equipment maintenance. More than 75% of IAQ problems are HVAC related, and poor IAQ results in reduced productivity of approximately 14.5 million missed workdays a year costing the US more than $168 B annually. Widespread adoption of this technology would help companies increase their productivity due to better indoor air quality. Several studies have concluded that poor indoor air quality results in reduced performance. Some of the studies have calculated the total costs associated with mold-related asthma and sinus issues alone to be up to $32 B in medical bills and absenteeism. The approach focuses on HVAC equipment and enabling preventive maintenance, which may save the manufacturing industry over $200 B annually.

This I-Corps project is focused on developing an intelligent monitoring and predictive system that is capable of 1) predicting future mold growth, 2) making predictions of future HVAC system health, and 3) generating alerts, work orders, and maintenance recommendations to the end user. Such a service does not currently exist within traditional building automation systems, which only monitor the mechanical systems with a focus on energy optimization, not the environment with a focus on occupant comfort. Facility managers continue to take a reactive approach to HVAC system maintenance and mold remediation, rather than a proactive, preventative approach. The goal is to evaluate several approaches to quantify the state of health of HVAC systems with limited data under the assumption that access to proprietary data is not possible. Time series analysis methods, such as vectorized auto regression, provide accurate anomaly detection results under a short prediction horizon, but are not suitable for fault isolation. Using mold growth and rate charts from the literature, a machine learning algorithm has been developed to accurately classify the risk level of a given temperature and humidity reading, but further work is needed to account for a cumulative exposure rate or measurement fluctuations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project assessed the viability of developing technology related to predicting and preventing mold growth and unforeseen HVAC failures with an intelligent monitoring and alerting system for facility environments. We found an overwhelming majority of stakeholders do not have access to such technology, and found that typical building mechanical systems do not provide predictive information regarding the HVAC system health to the user. We also found a large interest in technology relating to indoor air quality monitoring and HVAC health prediction, but generally, nothing significant related to mold growth. This provided a product-market opportunity. As the project progressed, we decided that to address the needs present in the facility management industry, it was advisable to pivot from mold growth prediction to indoor air quality monitoring and mechanical system fault prediction. We have since followed this up with an SBIR submission to the AI topic related to this pivot.

Dominant industry beliefs falsely assume that HVAC and building automation systems (BAS) properly control building environments 24/7, ensure that indoor air quality (IAQ) is maximized, and mechanical systems operate efficiently. In reality, those systems solely focus on the operation of proprietary mechanical equipment to reduce energy costs and rely on building occupants themselves to monitor and report on actual environmental conditions. The intellectual merit of this research lies in the study of this fragmented ecosystem to understand why there is such a disconnected between what building operation think their mechanical system is doing, and what is actually happening in the environment.

We found most customers prioritize energy management over other projects due to well-crafted performance-based contracts that make it seem as if the school saves money over time. However, in the case of [company name removed] and [company name removed], and several other first-hand accounts, such claims are not easily verified and have resulted in legal action. Second on the priority list is a preventative maintenance (PM) program. Roughly one third of the stakeholders we spoke to have not even implemented a PM program on their HVAC equipment, half of the customers have “somewhat of a PM program”, and only about 1/6 of the customers could fully articulate what their PM program is. Finally, there is IAQ, which is a “hot topic” for many of the facility managers we spoke to, but none of the school districts had a funded IAQ program. One district we interviewed is in the middle of a class action lawsuit by occupants who experienced respiratory issues due to the poor air quality of the buildings.

A majority of the Building Automation System (BAS) companies are focused on energy optimization and helping customers schedule their maintenance activities based on hours of operation, rather than the actual state of health of the system or the current environmental conditions. Our solution does not need to need to make direct measurements on the equipment, and it is the only one offering actual predictive technology (not based on predefined schedules). It should be noted that, while our technology does not focus directly on equipment and energy, our algorithms do verify equipment operation and, therefore, can predict the future state of health of the HVAC system.

The broader impacts of this research directly address occupant health and IAQ. People spend roughly 1/3 of their life in a facility environment where the IAQ is directly impacted by the health of the mechanical systems that circulate the air. Several studies have shown that poor IAQ results in increased health problems, more doctor visits, productivity loss, and reduced learning outcomes. This project validated the need for better and cheaper IAQ technology in the public domain and such technology has the potential to improve the quality of an occupants experience and health outcomes in a facility by ensuring adequate indoor air quality standards are met.
